questions.text: Which of the following is not a fibrous joint?
questions.solution:
Symphysis is not a fibrous joint, but a secondary cartilaginous joint.

Structurally, joints are classified as fibrous joints, cartilaginous joints, and synovial joints (see the table). Sutures, syndesmosis, and gomphosis are fibrous joints. Symphysis and synchondrosis are types of cartilaginous joints. 

Structural classification of joints
Type  Subtypes
Fibrous joints
  • Sutures
  • Syndesmosis
  • Gomphosis
Cartilaginous joints
  • Primary cartilaginous joints (or synchondrosis)
  • Secondary cartilaginous joints (or symphysis)
 Synovial joints
  • Ball-and-socket or spheroidal joints
  • Sellar or saddle joints
  • Condylar or bicondylar joints
  • Ellipsoid joints
  • Hinge joints
  • Pivot or trochoid joints
  • Plane joints

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has a resting heart rate of 70-beats/min. The pressure-volume diagram of her left ventricle is given below. What is her cardiac output (in mL/min)? (Point 2 corresponds to 120 ml)
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient has a heart rate of 70-beats/min and the stroke volume can be determined from the given pressure-volume diagram.

Point 2 corresponds to the EDV(End diastolic volume) = 120 mL
Point 1 corresponds to the ESV(End systolic volume) = 50 mL

Thus, stroke volume (SV) = EDV – ESV = 120 – 50 = 70 mL

Therefore, Cardiac output = HR X SV = 70 X 70 = 4900 mL/min.

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presented with pain in the calf muscles on exercise. On biopsy, an excessive amount of glycogen was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are seen in McArdle's disease. This patient has muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency.

The lack of muscle glycogen phosphorylase results in excess glycogen build-up in muscles, as seen in the biopsy.

Image: Vacuolar myopathy in McArdle's disease

Features:

  • Poor exercise tolerance
  • Abnormally high muscle glycogen (2.5-4%)
  • Very low blood lactate after exercise

Image: Myophosphorylase enzyme histochemistry showing

(A) Normal muscle

(B) - McArdle's disease

Related Pearl: Glycogen Storage Diseases

(Acid maltase)

questions.text: Which of the following stains is used for the detection of hemosiderin deposits?
questions.solution:
Perl's Prussian blue stain is used to detect Hemosiderin deposits.

Hemosiderin is a hemoglobin-derived granular pigment that is golden yellow to brown. It accumulates in the tissues when there is a local or systemic excess of iron.

Iron is normally stored within cells in association with the protein apoferritin, forming ferritin micelles. Large aggregates of these micelles are hemosiderin deposits seen both in light and electron microscopy. 

Image 1: Hemosiderin deposits in tissue

Image 2: Prussian Blue Staining of hemosiderin

Note:

  • Iron dispersed in the cytoplasm is seen in electron microscopy as ferritin micelles.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

Staining technique Uses
H&E Most common stain used in routine histopathology
Papanicolaou stain Universal stain for cytological preparations
PAS Demonstrate glycogen, mucin, fungi, macrophages in Whipple's disease, adenocarcinomas, and glycogen- positive tumors (Ewings sarcoma, renal-cell carcinoma)
Alcian blue For acid mucins: Positive stain for mucins of the intestinal mucosa and negative stain for mucins of gastric mucosa and Brunner's gland
Perl's Prussian blue Demonstrate hemosiderin and iron
Masson–Fontana stain Demonstrate melanin in nevus and malignant melanoma
von Kossa method Demonstrate calcium
Van Gieson stain

Demonstrate collagen in spindle-cell neoplasm; Delineate extent of fibrosis; Differentiate amyloid from collagen
Masson trichrome stain Demonstrate collagen and muscle in connective tissue disorders, muscle and fibroblast tumors, liver cirrhosis, neuromuscular diseases
Reticulin stain Demonstrate reticulin fibers to distinguish epithelial from non-epithelial neoplasm, Hodgkin's lymphoma, early cirrhosis of the liver, myelofibrosis
Verhoeff's method Demonstrate elastic fibers in malignant hypertension, arteriovenous malformation aneurysms, Marfan's syndrome, emphysema lung
Oil red O Sudan Black Sudan III/IV Demonstrate fat/lipids: Fatty liver-fat embolism-fibroma vs. thecoma of the ovary-liposarcoma

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with hepatitis B infection. Which of the following markers will always be present in his serum, even during recurrences, or if he develops chronic hepatitis?
questions.solution:
A patient who has had exposure to HBV will have Anti HBc antibodies even when he has moved into the chronic or recurrent stages. IgM anti-HBc reappears during acute recurrences while IgG Anti HBc is found in chronic states. 

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

 Clinical Phases HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc HBV DNA
Acute HBV - Early-phase, high infectivity

+

 - + - IgM +++

Acute HBV -Window phase

-

 - - - IgM +

Acute HBV - recovery phase

-

 + - + IgG +/-
Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG +++

Chronic HBV, low infectivity

 + - - + IgG +

HBV infection in the recent past

 - + - - IgG -

HBV infection in the remote past

 - - - +/- IgG -

Post-vaccination

 - + - - - -

questions.text: A child on beta 2 agonists for the treatment of bronchial asthma may exhibit all of the following except:
questions.solution:
β2 agonists are associated with hyperglycemia probably due to β2 receptor-mediated glycogenolysis and glucagon release.

Adverse effects of beta 2 agonists are

  • Muscle tremors: Direct effect on beta 2 receptors in skeletal muscles and due to hypokalemia
  • Tachycardia: Direct effect on cardiac beta 2 receptors, indirect sympathetic stimulation due to vasodilator action on beta 2 receptors
  • Hypokalemia: Direct effect on skeletal muscle uptake of K+ ions
  • Hypoxemia
  • Hyperglycaemia
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Tolerance: Desensitization on long-term use

questions.text: What type of skull fracture is shown in the given image:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a gutter fracture of the skull.

It is a furrow in the outer table of the skull, ordinarily the result of a glancing blow by a missile from a rifled firearm. These are frequently accompanied with comminuted depressed fractures of inner table of the skull.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture - Separation of sutures due to blow with blunt weapon or from cerebral edema. It is also called sutural fracture.

Fissured fracture/Linear fracture:

  • Linear skull fractures are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture - Occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. It is also known as indented fracture.

Depressed fracture - Caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced. So it is also called 'signature fracture'.

Comminuted fracture - It is also called spider web fracture and has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of fracture.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding serous otitis media?

choices.text: Adenoid hypertrophy is the most common cause in children causing bilateral serous otitis media
Tumors of nasopharynx is most common cause in adults causing unilateral serous otitis media

questions.solution:
All the given statements are true.

Serous otitis media: 

The fluid is nearly sterile and the causes are :

Malfunctioning of eustachian tube:

  • Adenoid hyperplasia in children.
  • Benign and malignant tumors of nasopharynx. This cause should always be excluded in unilateral serous otitis media in an adult.

Other causes include

  • Interference with ET opening like in cleft lip and cleft palate and enlarged tonsils
  • Otitic barotrauma
  • Increased middle ear secretions like in an allergy.
  • Persistent effusion of ASOM due to inadequate treatment dose or duration

questions.text: A 30-day-old infant is brought with excessive lacrimation and photophobia. He has a large and hazy cornea in both eyes. His lacrimal system is normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario fits the description of congenital glaucoma.

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG)

It can be classified as follows:

  • True congenital glaucoma (40%) in which intraocular pressure (IOP) is elevated during intrauterine life.
  • Infantile glaucoma (55%), which manifests prior to age 3.
  • Juvenile glaucoma, the least common, in which IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Several genes have been implicated, prominently CYP1B1.

Diagnosis

  • Corneal haze is due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP.
  • Buphthalmos is a large eye as a result of stretching due to elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years.
  • Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane.
  • Corneal scarring
  • Evaluation under general anesthesia is generally required; sevoflurane lowers IOP to levels lower than those achieved with other agents.

Treatment

  • Management is essentially surgical.
  • Goniotomy
  • Trabeculotomy
  • Other procedures when angle surgery fails include trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures.

questions.text: Example of multiphasic screening is _____

choices.text: Chest X-ray for TB in large populations
Pap smear in women above 40 years
Random blood sugar during antenatal visits

questions.solution:
Example of multiphasic screening is annual health checkups.

Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests in combination to a large number of people at one time.

High-risk or selective screening is done on high-risk groups example- MRI screening of breast done annually in 25-year old women with BRCA 1, BRCA 2 mutations in first degree relative .

Pap smears screening as per American Cancer Society (ACS) should start at age 21. Women aged <21 years should not be screened regardless of the age of sexual initiation or other risk factors. 

Mass screening is a screening of a whole or large population like using chest X-ray for TB screening in large populations. It is done for diseases with high prevalence.

questions.text: The insect shown below is a vector for a disease that is targetted under the national vector-borne disease control program. Identify the disease caused by this vector.
questions.solution:
The image shown is of the Culex species of mosquitoes, which is a vector for Japanese Encephalitis and Bancroftian filariasis. 

Mansonia species is the vector for Malayan filariasis.

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis,Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 
  • Called "Nuisance mosquitoes"
  • These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called as tiger mosquitoes and they are day biters

They get the"tiger" name from white stripes  on its legs.

 Mansonia mosquitoes are big, black or brown mosquitoes with sparkling on their wings and

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution.
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes and Mansonia.
  • Flight range varies up to 11 kms, except Aedes for which it is 100 metres.
  • Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days.
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen.

Charateristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia
EggsUsually 100-250. This stage lasts 1 – 2 days. Laid singly; boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star shaped clusters.
Larval stageThis stage lasts for 5 -7 days.

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Stripped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artifical collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis,Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 
  • Called "Nuisance mosquitoes"
  • These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called as tiger mosquitoes and they are day biters

They get the"tiger" name from white stripes  on its legs.

 Mansonia mosquitoes are big, black or brown mosquitoes with sparkling on their wings and legs. 

 

 

  • Culex mosquito, they keep their bodies horizontal while feeding:

 

  • Anopheles mosquito as seen in the image below, they tend to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high:

 

  • Aedes mosquito (aegypti), as seen in the image below, their bodies are striped:

questions.text: Which of the following items are disposed of in the yellow bag?
questions.solution:
Blood bags are disposed of in the yellow bag.

Gloves are disposed of in the red bag.

Sharps are disposed of in the white container.

Urine bags are disposed of in the red bag.

Related Pearl: Biomedical waste disposal

The changes as per the new Biomedical waste management (amendment) rules, 2018 have been included in the above table and highlighted in green.

 Note: Ash from incineration of biomedical waste shall be disposed of at common hazardous waste treatment and disposal facility. However, it may be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with severe pancreatitis. The next day he develops sudden onset breathlessness and severe hypoxia. Below is the CXR obtained. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of severe pancreatitis and the chest X-ray findings of B/L diffuse alveolar opacities are suggestive of ARDS.

Severe pancreatitis gives rise to inflammatory processes and endothelial damage that results in ARDS. 

CXR features in ARDS:

  • Early findings include normal or diffuse alveolar opacities (consolidation), which are often bilateral and which obscure the pulmonary vascular markings.
  • Later, these opacities progress to more extensive consolidation that is diffuse.

Prolonged bed rest increases the risk of venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. However, the CXR shows diffuse alveolar opacities making the diagnosis of ARDS more likely.

Hospital-acquired pneumonia usually appears after 48 hours of admission. Areas of consolidation in unilateral or bilateral lung fields may be seen depending on severity. 

Left ventricular failure is an important differential diagnosis for ARDS. However, the patient's history of acute pancreatitis makes the diagnosis of ARDS more likely.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with a past medical history of generalized seizures controlled with phenytoin therapy. She had mild pallor on physical examination. Lab values reveal Hb -  9.8 g/dl, MCV - 106 fL, Platelets - 1,80,000/cu.mm, leukocytes - 7800/cu.mm. Which of the following supplementations could have prevented this anemia?
questions.solution:
This patient has mild megaloblastic anemia (high MCV), probably due to chronic phenytoin therapy. Some anti-epileptic drugs like phenytoin, phenobarbital can cause megaloblastic anemia by impairing absorption of folate in the small intestine. Folic acid supplementation can prevent this condition.

Related Pearl: Difference between B12 and Folic acid Deficiency

Laboratory Tests

Pernicious Anemia (B12 Deficiency)

Folic Acid Deficiency

Serum B12 level

Decreased

Normal

Serum folic acid level

Normal

Decreased

Serum LDH level

Increased

Normal

Achlorhydria

Present

Absent

Schilling Test

Positive

Negative

Methyl malonyl CoA in urine

Present

Absent

Neurological signs

Present

Absent

questions.text: A patient comes with a blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg and left-sided facial paralysis and weakness since 1 hour. Her CT appears normal. What would be your next step?
questions.solution:
Sudden onset hemiparesis with apparently normal CT indicates ischemic stroke in this patient.

Intravenous thrombolysis (alteplase: 0.9 mg/kg ) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in window period (within 3/4.5 hours of symptom onset).

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard investigation for diagnosis of COVID-19?

choices.text: Reverse transcription - polymerase chain reaction test

questions.solution:
The gold standard for the diagnosis of Covid-19 is the identification of viral genome targets in the respiratory tract materials by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) during the first week of symptoms.

RT-PCR: This method involves the reverse transcription of the genetic material of the virus (RNA) to complementary DNA (cDNA), followed by amplification of some regions of the cDNA.

Rapid antigen test (RAT): Antigen-based assays are used as point-of-care tests for early detection of SARS-CoV-2. They are used at the field level for early detection of infection and quick containment. Most of such tests have relatively moderate sensitivity but high specificity. They are used for diagnosis along with RT-PCR. 

Antibody testing: Antibodies of IgA, IgM, and IgG isotypes specific to different virus proteins are detected by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) or chemiluminescence immunoassays (CLIA). CLIA is more sensitive compared to ELISA.

questions.text: A 32-year-old boxer was brought to the emergency following a blow to the abdomen. On examination, his vitals are normal. He has tenderness in the abdomen. Which among the following will be the best modality to assess injury to his abdominal organs?
questions.solution:
A contrast-enhanced CT scan is the best diagnostic modality (gold standard) for stable patients with blunt trauma to the abdomen.

It is a non-invasive and sensitive investigation. It can identify hemorrhage, intraabdominal as well as retroperitoneal organ injury. However, performing CECT is time-consuming (when compared to FAST) and therefore it can be used only in stable patients.

FAST ultrasound is a limited examination to look for intraperitoneal fluid or pericardial injury as a marker of the underlying injury. The best imaging modality for hemodynamically unstable patients with blunt trauma of the abdomen is FAST.

MRI is typically not the first-line imaging modality in the acute setting of abdominal trauma, as it may not be as readily available or as quick to perform as a CT scan. MRI may be considered in cases with a specific concern for soft tissue injuries.

questions.text: All are true about the inguinal canal except _________.

choices.text: Conjoint tendon forms a part of the posterior wall.
Superficial ring is an opening in the external oblique aponeurosis.
Deep ring is an opening in the transverse abdominis.
Internal oblique forms both the anterior and posterior walls.

questions.solution:
The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia, not in the transverse abdominis.

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal

It is a 4 cm long intermuscular canal directed downwards, forwards and medially.

It extends from deep inguinal ring to superficial ring.

Boundaries:

  • Anterior:
    • External oblique aponeurosis
    • Internal oblique muscle (in lateral 1/3rd)
  • Superior wall/roof:
    • Internal oblique
    • Transverse abdominis
  • Posterior wall:
    • Fascia transversalis
    • Conjoint tendon (Internal oblique + Transverse abdominis)
  • Inferior wall/floor:
    • Inguinal ligament/Poupart ligament (Rolled out Inferior edge of the external oblique aponeurosis and extends from the anterior superior iliac spine to the pubic tubercle)
    • Lacunar ligament at medial end (fan-shaped medial expansion of the inguinal ligament)

Deep inguinal ring: Oval opening in fascia transversalis situated 1.25cm above mid-inguinal point.

Superficial inguinal ring: Triangular opening in external oblique aponeurosis situated 1cm above and lateral to pubic crest.

questions.text: A 34 year old construction worker with no comorbidities presents with exertional pain in both forearms and hands. He smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day. On examination, brachial pulses are palpable but radial and ulnar pulses are feeble. Image  of his hand is shown. Angiography of his upper extremity shows smooth tapering segmental lesions in the distal arterial vessels. Which of the following treatments has the greatest chances of success?
questions.solution:
This is a classical clinical scenario of thromboangiitis obliterans. There is no specific treatment except abstinence from tobacco.

Key points in the question:

  • Male < 40years
  • Smoker
  • Involvement of upper extremity
  • Raynauds phenomenon

Thromboangiitis Obliterans (Buerger’s disease):

  • An inflammatory occlusive vascular disorder involving small and medium-sized arteries and veins in the distal upper and lower extremities.
  • Most common in men <40 years of age.
  • Although the cause of thromboangiitis obliterans is not known, there is a definite relationship to cigarette smoking in patients with this disorder.
  • MRA, CTA, and conventional arteriography show smooth, tapering segmental lesions in the distal vessels with collateral vessels at sites of vascular occlusion.
  • There is no specific treatment except abstention from tobacco.
  • The prognosis is worse in individuals who continue to smoke, but results are discouraging even in those who stop smoking.
  • Antibiotics may be useful.
  • Anticoagulants and glucocorticoids are not helpful.
  • If these measures fail, amputation may be required.

No Smoking Day is observed every year on the second Wednesday of March. The aim of the campaign is to encourage people over the world to quit smoking. The main purpose of this day is to spread awareness about the harmful health effects of tobacco consumption through cigarette and other modes.

questions.text: A woman is admitted to the hospital for the management of breast cancer. The tumor is 3 cm in size with ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes. There is no distant metastasis. The TNM staging of tumor is:
questions.solution:
The TNM staging of the tumor is T2 N1 M0.

  • Tumor size 3 cm: T2 
  • Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes: N1
  • No distant metastasis: M0

Points to remember

  • In tumor size assessment, the greatest dimension is taken into consideration. For example, in a 6 x 2 cm lump, 6 cm is taken into account, and the tumor is classified as T3 (>5 cm).
  • Skin involvement does not include nipple retraction and skin dimpling.
  • Any contralateral lymph node involvement is considered as distant metastasis.
  • If 2 lumps are present in the same breast, staging is according to the bigger lump.
  • If lumps are present in both breasts, separate staging is done for both the lumps.

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of carcinoma breast

Tumor (T) Description
Tis Ductal carcinoma in situ / Paget's disease
T1

≤2 cm in greatest dimension

1a >0.1 to 0.5 cm

1b >0.5 to 1 cm

1c >1 to 2 cm
T2 >2 but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension
T3 >5 cm in greatest dimension
T4

Tumor of any size and -

4a – chest wall involvement (except pectoralis major)# 

4b – skin involvement in the form of ulceration, peau d’orange, satellite nodules  

4c – 4a + 4b  

4d – inflammatory breast carcinoma(typical skin changes involving >1/3rd of breast)*
Nodes (N) Description
N1 mic Refers to micrometastasis to Lymph node
N1 Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes
N2A Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes
N2B Ipsilateral internal mammary without axillary lymph node involvement
N3A Ipsilateral infraclavicular lymph nodes
N3B Ipsilateral internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes
N3C Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes
Distant metastasis (M) Description
Metastasis absent M0
Metastasis present M1

  

Stages       T , N  M
Stage 0 TisN0 M0
Stage IA T1N0 M0
Stage IB T0,1N1mic M0
Stage IIA T0,1N1 (or) T2N0 M0
Stage IIB T2N1 (or) T3N0 M0
Stage IIIA T0,1,2,3N2 (or) T3N1 M0
Stage IIIB T4 N0,1,2 M0
Stage IIIC

Any T, N3

 M0
Stage IV

Any T, Any N

 M1

#Chest wall includes Serratus anterior, Intercostal muscles, Ribs. Pectoralis muscle is not a part of chest wall.

*Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage IIIB) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peaud’orange) involving >1/3rd of breast.

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered as a benign condition and not included under Tis.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely physiological change in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Decrease in peripheral vascular resistance is a physiologial change in pregnancy. 

Parameters increasing in pregnancy:

  • Cardiac output
  • Stroke volume
  • Heart rate

Parameters decreasing in pregnancy:

  • Peripheral vascular resistance (due to smooth muscle relaxation by progesterone)
  • Both diastolic BP and systolic BP (decrease in DBP > SBP)
  • Mean arterial BP
  • Artery venous O2 gradient

Late pregnancy was associated with decreased systemic vascular and pulmonary vascular resistance both decreased significantly, as did colloid osmotic pressure.

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: The partogram of a 28 year old G2P1 is shown below. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The above partogram shows a case of obstructed labour and management is a caesarean section.

There is a secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hours and arrest of descent for >1 hour. The patient has adequate uterine contractions as shown. The amniotic fluid is stained with meconium and there is fall in fetal heart rate which indicates that the baby is in distress.

There is no place for wait and watch and use of oxytocin to stimulate uterine contractions in obstructed labor.

 

The WHO partograph is a repeatedly tested topic in the NBE and Central Institute exams.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: Identify the hysterosalpingogram.
questions.solution:
The image shows normal hysterosalpingogram (HSG).

Note both fallopian tubes are patent with spill into peritoneal cavity.

Hysterosalpingogram: Filling defects:

Above HSG showing bilateral dilated Fallopian tubes with no free spill suggestive of bilateral hydrosalpinx

Above HSG showing unicornuate uterus

Above HSG showing bicornuate uterus/septate uterus.

questions.text: “Social smile” is typically seen at ____ months and “stranger anxiety,” at ____ months.
questions.solution:
Social smile is typically seen at 2 months and stranger anxiety at 6 months.

Social smile: At 1 month of age, a child smiles involuntarily. At 2 months of age social smile develops; that is, the child smiles voluntarily and reciprocally, in response to someone else’s smile.

Stranger anxiety: Before 6 months, the child is sociable and friendly even with strangers. At 6 months, there is an onset of stranger anxiety; infants look back and forth between an approaching stranger and parent and may cling or cry anxiously.

Related Pearl: Social and adaptive milestones

 
Age
Milestone
2 months
Social smile
3 months
Recognizes mother
6 months
Stranger anxiety

Plays simple ball game
15 months

3 years
Shares toys
Knows full name and gender
4 years
Plays cooperatively in a group and goes to the toilet alone
5 years
Helps in household tasks and can dress and undress on its own

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman presents with a history of pain in the forearm after falling down the stairs. The plain radiograph is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and radiograph are suggestive of Colles’ fracture.

The radiograph shows a transverse fracture of the radius just above the wrist. The fracture appears extra-articular. In the AP view, the distal fracture fragment is dorsally angulated. This is characteristic of Colles' fracture.  

Displacements that may be seen in Colles' fracture:

  • Dorsal tilt
  • Dorsal shift
  • Lateral tilt (Radial tilt)
  • Lateral shift (Radial shift)
  • Supination
  • Impaction of fragments

The clinical feature includes dinner fork deformity with prominence on the back of the wrist and depression in the front. It is treated by a Colles’ cast, which immobilizes the wrist in palmar flexion, pronation, and ulnar deviation.

Complications:

  • Stiffness of joints: Finger stiffness is commonly seen
  • Malunion - can produce dinner-fork deformity
  • Subluxation of the inferior radio-ulnar joint
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome - Uncommon
  • Sudek's osteodystrophy - Colles' fracture is the commonest cause of this condition in the upper limb.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis based on the image of the scan given below?
questions.solution:
The given MRI of the brain demonstrates a papillary craniopharyngioma: mainly solid suprasellar mass without calcifications and without T1 hyperintensity. 

  • It develops from the persistent remnants of the original connection between the Rathke's pouch and the oral cavity. 
  • Adamantinomatous (children) and Papillary (adult) are two variants of craniopharyngioma.
  • Calcification is characteristic of the adamantinomatous variety and predominates in childhood.
  • These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components.
  • The cysts contain a cholesterol rich, thick brownish yellow fluid that is compared to "machine oil".

Symptoms include headache and visual changes (bitemporal hemianopia) as well as endocrinologic abnormalities such as growth failure and delayed sexual maturation due to pituitary hypofunction and GH deficiency.

  • MRI:
    • cysts
      • T1: iso- to hyperintense to brain (due to high protein content "machinery oil cysts")
      • T2: Mostly hyperintense
    • solid component
      • T1 C+ (Gd): vivid enhancement
      • T2: variable or mixed

questions.text: Wernicke-Korsakoff psychosis is seen due to the deficiency of ______.
questions.solution:
Wernicke-Korsakoff psychosis is seen due to the deficiency of thiamine. Thiamine is a cofactor for several important enzymes and is also involved in the conduction of the axon potential and synaptic transmission.

Wernicke's encephalopathy/alcoholic encephalopathy is an acute neurological disorder.

The triad of symptoms seen is (GOA):

  • Global Confusion
  • Ophthalmoplegia ( first symptom to improve with thiamine +dextrose infusion)
  • Ataxia

Treatment

It is a medical emergency and requires immediate administration of thiamine 100 mg IV or IM for 3 days followed by two to three times a day orally for 1 to 2 weeks.

Glucose infusions may precipitate Wernicke’s disease in a previously unaffected patient or cause a rapid worsening of an early form of the disease. For this reason, thiamine should be administered to all alcoholic patients requiring parenteral glucose.

questions.text: The appropriate size for the following device is chosen by measuring the distance between?

choices.text: Incisor teeth and tragus of the ear
Corner of mouth and angle of mandible
Tip of nose and angle of mandible
Ala of nose and angle of mandible

questions.solution:
The image shows oropharyngeal airways of various sizes.

The appropriate size is chosen by measuring the distance between the corner of a patient’s mouth to the angle of mandible. 

An oropharyngeal airway is an airway device which keeps the tongue from falling back onto the posterior pharynx.

It is essential to choose the correct size since inappropriately sized ones may aggravate airway obstruction. 

Note: Nasopharyngeal airway size is chosen by measuring the distance between the tip of the nose and tragus of the ear.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The image is of Atopic dermatosis.

Atopic dermatosis is a relapsing inflammatory skin disorder that is common in infancy and presents differently in different age groups. It is characterized by pruritus leading to lichenification.

Clinical features:

  • In infants: The lesions most frequently start on the face, and then, the extensor aspect of the knees and elbows are involved.
  • In Children: Dry, scaly, pruritic, excoriated papules and plaques in the flexural areas and neck.
  • In adults: Lichenification and dry, fissured skin in a flexural distribution.

questions.text: 4R’s of Radiotherapy are:
questions.solution:
In general, success or failure of standard clinical radiation treatment is determined by the 4 R’s of radiobiology: repair of DNA damage, redistribution of cells in the cell cycle, repopulation, and reoxygenation of hypoxic tumor areas.

5th R of radiotherapy is radiosensitivity.
